episodes.title: Is My Relationship DOOMED? | Unpacking John Gottman's 5 Principles of Trust
episodes.description: "Is my relationship doomed"? If you've ever asked yourself this question, this is the conversation for you. In this incredibly important episode, we discuss the five principles of trust laid out by John Gottman in the Science of Trust which are crucial for identifying healthy (or toxic and predatory) relationships. It is very important to be able to recognize trustworthiness in relationships. Drawing from John Gottman's book 'The Science of Trust,' we explore five key principles: honesty, transparency, accountability, ethics, and alliance. We share our personal experiences with predatory relationships, emphasizing the need for clarity and agency to protect oneself. We also want to encourage listeners to actively apply these principles in your relationships to identify and avoid harmful dynamics. Join the conversation and learn how to empower yourself to spot predators and cultivate trustworthy relationships. Don't forget to like, comment and subscribe to us at @preyvspredatorpodcast! episodes.title: Post Traumatic Church Disorder | Understanding Religious Coercive Control
episodes.description: In order to gain a better understanding of religious coercive control it is important to understand post traumatic church disorder. In this episode of Prey versus Predator, with our guest Sarah, we discuss the impact of coercive religions and relationships on individuals, focusing on the concept of 'Post Traumatic Church Syndrome.' Sarah, from Sacred Unraveling, shares her personal story of leaving a coercive religion and an abusive relationship. She describes how both experiences had profound effects on her mental health, self-esteem, and ability to recognize and respond to red flags. Sarah outlines her journey of deconstruction - critically examining and re-evaluating her beliefs, leading to a process of healing and empowerment. In the second part of the episode, Sarah highlights the importance of having resources and language to understand and articulate experiences with coercion and abuse. Through Sacred Unraveling, Sarah aims to provide support and hope to others in similar situations, offering insights on recognizing abuse, reclaiming personal power, and the path to recovery. The discussion emphasizes the role of community, awareness, and the empowering realization that survivors have voices and choices. episodes.title: Ways To Spot A Predator | Lessons of Coercive Control From A Classic Fairy Tale
episodes.description: What are ways to spot a predator? Surprisingly, there are lessons of coercive control to glean from classic fairy tales! Through a close reading of Little Red Riding Hood, we can actually find some helpful insights into predatory tactics! In this episode of Prey VS Predator, we explore elements of coercive control through the lens of this classic fairy tale, and look into how the wolf's behavior—using love bombing, dismissiveness, and feigning victimhood—parallels the tactics of predators in real life. We also examine how predators often manipulate perceptions to appear as victims, confusing their prey and exploiting their caregiving instincts. We hope this episode equips you with the knowledge and strategies to guard against predatory behavior, fostering a deeper understanding of coercive control dynamics in various contexts. episodes.title: This is Coercive Control: Navigating the Nightmare of Post-Separation Abuse
episodes.description: This is Coercive Control, and the nightmare of Post-Separation Abuse. Welcome to Part 2 of our conversation with Courtney Gilmartin from New Jersey Protective Moms. In this episode, we discuss the realities of dealing with coercive control within the context of separation and custody battles. Courtney shares her journey of escaping an abusive relationship, only to face ongoing legal and personal challenges, including manipulation, stalking, and intimidation from her ex-husband, even in the presence of law enforcement and judicial oversight. Despite obtaining multiple restraining orders and engaging in legal battles for the safety of herself and her children, Courtney details the systemic failures that often re-victimize survivors. She highlights the importance of understanding coercive control, the impact on children, and the struggle for legal recognition of non-physical forms of abuse. Courtney also discusses her advocacy work through NJprotectivemoms.org, aiming to support other survivors and push for legislative changes to address coercive control and abusive litigation in family law. episodes.title: This is how a Narcissist Isolates Their Victim... What are 'Flying Monkeys'?
episodes.description: This sneaky tactic is how abusers and narcissists isolate their victims. It's called flying monkeys, and it's as insidious as it sounds. Welcome back to Prey Versus Predator. In this episode we explore the concept of 'flying monkeys' within the context of abusive relationships and narcissistic manipulation. A flying monkey is someone who a predator enlists in order to alienate and harass their victims in order to further the victim's isolation and trauma. We share many personal examples of how we have experienced these Flying Monkeys in our own lives. This episode offers insights on recognizing and dealing with flying monkeys, advocating for victims to establish boundaries and protect themselves from further harm. Additionally, it provides advice for listeners to avoid becoming flying monkeys themselves, highlighting the importance of questioning narratives that paint others in a negative light without evidence. episodes.title: Shiny Happy People and Controlling Cults | The Shocking Story of IFB Survivor Chad Harris
episodes.description: Chad Harris from Shiny Happy People shares his shocking story of living the majority of his life under the Controlling Cults known as the Independent Fundamental Baptist (IFB) Movement and the Advanced Training Institute (ATI). We are so excited to have Chad Harris on Prey VS Predator. Chad discusses his background growing up and living in the Independent Fundamental Baptist (IFB) church cult. Chad was raised in a strict and isolated environment, where his upbringing was marked by fear, emotional, and physical abuse under the guise of religious discipline. We learned that a turning point came when Chad began to question the abusive and secretive practices within the church, especially after learning about alleged crimes committed by respected members of the community, including Bill Gothard. Chad was mainly met with silence and avoidance, particularly from his father, a preacher who had previously been vocal against other injusticies. This revelation prompted Chad to leave the church, seek therapy, and eventually share his story publicly, contributing to the ‘Shiny Happy People’ docu-series on Amazon. We also dive into the complexities of distinguishing between Prey and Predator roles within such controlling environments, questioning how power dynamics and fear can silence dissent and perpetuate abuse. episodes.title: Is My Partner A Narcissist? | The 5 Stages of Narcissistic Abuse with Abuse Expert Dr. Tamara Knott
episodes.description: Is my partner a narcissist? That is a question that Dr. Tamara Knott seeks to answer through sharing her groundbreaking research on the five stages of narcissistic abuse. Dr. Tamara Knott has done extensive research on the stages of relationships with narcissistic partners. She identifies five stages: the foundations of the relationship, where partners experience some life transition; the stage below the surface, where one gets a peek at the narcissist's manipulative behaviors; the roller coaster stage, characterized by intense ups and downs; the recovery and leaving stage, where people start the recovery process before leaving the relationship; and the hindsight stage, where people look back on the relationship with clarity. We also take a look at the innate skills that narcissists possess and their ability to lure in and manipulate prey for long-term benefits. The conversation also touches on the origins of narcissistic behavior, suggesting it is a combination of nature and nurture. Dr. Knott emphasizes the importance of education and empowerment for those affected by narcissistic abuse. She offers counseling services through her website, www.adventurecounseling.com, and provides online counseling for those around the world. We hope you enjoy the episode, and don't forget to like, comment and subscribe to us at @preyvspredatorpodcast ! Spread the word. episodes.title: Healing Trauma Through Mindfulness: A Beginner's Guide To Abuse Recovery Through Mindfulness
episodes.description: Mindfulness. Believe it or not, this is a powerful tool for anyone seeking greater emotional resilience and healing. In this episode of the Prey VS Predator podcast as we explore a powerful tool for recovering prey: mindfulness. Our returning guest, Sophia, shares her story of overcoming emotional trauma and rebuilding her life using mindfulness strategies, rooted in experience and academic studies. Sophia unpacks how mindfulness is not only about meditation but a building a lifestyle of intentionality that cultivates awareness and presence in our everyday lives. Whether you're new to mindfulness or looking to deepen your practice, this podcast is packed with wisdom and practical advice. episodes.title: BOUNDARIES PT 2: How Healthy Boundaries Can Shield You From ABUSE!
episodes.description: Did you know that establishing healthy boundaries can protect you from emotional abuse? Welcome back to Prey VS Predator, and part 2 of our series on boundaries! In this episode of our podcast, we dive into the importance of maintaining healthy boundaries in relationships, and how this can be an essential tool for prey to protect themselves from abuse. We explore predatory tactics like 'hoovering', used to lure the prey back into relationships, and unpack the distinction between accidental VS deliberate boundary violations. Acknowledging and respecting each other's boundaries is an undeniable part of any healthy relationship, and while it can be incredibly hard to uphold your own boundaries, it really is necessary for self-protection and self-respect. If you're in a relationship with a predator, understanding the dynamics of boundaries can not only be useful for self-protection, but it can also help you identify early signs of predatory behaviour that lead to abuse, such as anger, rage, resentment and rejection. Does any of this sound familiar? We would love to hear your story. episodes.title: Confronting a Narcissist: One Woman's Courageous Journey of Healing | Sophia’s Story (PT3)
episodes.description: Confronting a narcissist: Sophia's courageous journey of escaping and healing from narcissistic abuse (PT3). In this episode of Prey VS Predator, we conclude our series with our guest Sophia. As we wrap up the conversation, Sophia shares the difficulty of confronting her community about her abusive husband's behaviour and the loss of many friends that followed this disclosure. Throughout this final chapter of our conversation, we explore the role of justice, compassion, and accountability when dealing with predators, especially in significant institutions such as the church. Sophia also stresses the importance of building mutually respectful relationships and the necessity of having an exit strategy and a supportive team when dealing with a controlling partner. This episode is filled with powerful insights about healing from abuse, setting boundaries, and recovering from abuse. If you're battling with similar experiences or know someone who is, Sophia’s story will definitely resonate... but also offer some hope. Don’t forget to reach out if you need help, and remember, you are not alone. We hope you enjoy the episode. *********************************************** PREY VS PREDATOR Follow us for regular updates and words of encouragement! episodes.title: My Story of Domestic Abuse: From Living in FEAR to Finding New Life | Jill's Story
episodes.description: Domestic abuse isn't always physical. A partner can be abusive in all sorts of other ways, no the least of which is manipulation and infidelity. This is Jill's story of intimate partner abuse. Jill's story is heartbreaking. Throughout her first marriage, her husband slowly showed himself to be a predator. But his abusive behaviour didn't start after they got married. According to Jill herself, her ex's predatory tendencies were clear to everyone around her... but not to her. Why? Why is it so hard to see the toxic behaviours in our partners? Why does it remain difficult even while we're in the middle of abuse? Why can we remain blind to it even while others, especially our kids, are telling us the person is no good? In this episode we explore the complexities of spousal abuse and how, even in the midst of abuse, there is hope. We hope this gives you some things to start thinking about and we hope you will engage with us further via Instagram, facebook or youtube! #preypower

episodes.title: When Your Ex is a Predator... How Do You Support Kids With a Predator Parent?
episodes.description: How can you support children who have a predator parent? This is a loaded question. Especially when you are already trying to distance yourself from your predator, setting up your own boundaries for self-care, how can you help your kids process and navigate their relationship with the predator when, quite often, it's not possible to cut ties completely? In this episode, we explore what a parent can do to support their child. Although you won't be able to protect them from abuse, you can help your children by working to be the best version of yourself, creating a safe place for your kids to experience their emotions, and working with your kids to develop a language for understanding their experiences. We hope this gives you some things to start thinking about and we hope you will engage with us further via Instagram, facebook or youtube! #preypower

episodes.title: Children of Domestic Abuse | Trauma, The Brain and Coercive Control with Dr. Christine Cocchiola
episodes.description: Traumatized Children, domestic abuse and the impact of Coercive Control. How do we respond to children who have witnessed and experienced domestic abuse at house? How does it impact their brain? How should we, as parents and trauma victims ourselves, raise them to be as resilient and healthy as possible? For this episode we are excited to welcome back Dr. Christine Cocchiola! Dr. Cocchiola is a licensed clinical social worker, college professor and all-around advocate for victims of intimate partner abuse. As a survivor of spousal abuse, Dr. Cocchiola works to educate and research Coercive Control, including child maltreatment and trauma. Her expertise is in the areas of intimate partner violence, trauma, and child abuse, developing and presenting workshops on these topics both nationally and internationally. She is also the creator of the Protective Parenting Program, a program aimed at supporting protective mothers on their journey of healing their children. In this episode, we explore how our language of “prey” and “predator” map onto Dr. Cocchiola’s research and dive deep into the language of Coercive Control. episodes.title: Your Story is NOT FOR EVERYONE! | How to Recover from Emotional Abuse
episodes.description: Brené Brown, a powerful voice in the area of emotional abuse, often says that to people, your story is not for everyone. Sharing our story can be an incredibly vulnerable thing. It opens us up and exposes us to the judgement of others, which is not something we should do lightly, especially as prey - victims of emotional abuse - who are eager to remove any barriers to deeper relationships. It's also dangerous to accept the narratives others have created for us, which is something predators do to maintain control. Being able to see and name this control tactic can help prey regain power over their identity and grow into greater confidence and self-assurance. Do you have questions or think you might be in a predatory relationship? We would love to hear from you to support and encourage you. episodes.description: Let's talk about leaving. Why not just leave an abusive relationship? If you’re dealing with a narcissist, or any predatory individual, why not just pick up and go? We hear this sort of question a lot, and, unfortunately, it’s never quite so simple. Whether it’s love-bombing, financial interdependence, children, mental clarity or any number of other factors, leaving is hardly ever easy. In this episode we explore our own stories and all the complexities of “why not just leave”? Does this sound familiar? We would love to hear your story. episodes.title: Are They A Narcissist? | Creating A Language for Emotional Abuse
episodes.description: What is emotional abuse? What does it look like when there are no bruises or broken arms? Have you ever been told by a partner, friend or family member, "I know you better than you know yourself"? What about “you don’t have my best interests at heart”? Do you feel constantly gaslit, misled or made to feel inferior and unworthy of love? It may seem benign and unintentional, but when these are patterns of behaviour (they are consistent and persistent) they become more than just momentary lapses in judgement or careless words - they become tactics used to shut up and shut down. Seeing these patterns can help us avoid these relationships or navigate them more effectively when we have to. Does this sound familiar? We would love to hear your story. episodes.title: Recognizing The Language of Emotional Abuse | Emotional Abuse Recovery (2022)
episodes.description: What is the language of abuse? Have you ever been told by a partner, friend of family member, "I know you better than you know yourself"? Amber, one of our hosts on this podcast, discusses how her mother used this phrase to control and manipulate - to tell her who she was and what she could accomplish. One of the most powerful ways predators control their prey is by imposing themselves on their prey’s story. They can do this by laying claim to an insider’s knowledge of another person, saying things like, “I know you better than you know yourself”. Amber experienced this with her mother who was constantly telling her who she was, her flaws and failures, and diminishing her successes. It may seem benign but this simple strategy is a powerful way predators shut up and shut down their prey. Does this sound familiar? We would love to hear your story. episodes.title: Welcome to Prey VS Predator! | How to Talk About Emotional Abuse
episodes.description: Welcome to Prey VS Predator! This podcast is all about helping people identify and put a language to emotional abuse. As survivors of emotional abuse, what we call PREY on this podcast, we three hosts (Jill, Amber and PJ) all draw from wells of personal experience to equip others with the language and tools they need to navigate relationships with predators. Tune in every week as we unpack what it means to be 'PREY' and 'PREDATOR', and how understanding these patterns of behavior can help us navigate our world.
